DOC.HEAD: Producer Recalling Cajun Food
DOC.TEXT: A Louisiana processor is voluntarily recalling about 1,000 pounds of a frozen pork and rice product because it might be contaminated with a food-poisoning organism, Listeria monocytogenes, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. Bodin Foods Inc. of New Iberia, La., sells the product through small distributors in Arizona, California, Florida, Louisiana and Texas. It is sold frozen in vacuum-sealed plastic packages with the name ``Boo Dan (Boudin Link) Traditional Cajun Pudding'' on the label, and ``Est. 8214'' printed inside the USDA inspection seal on the label. A USDA spokesman said the product is cooked pork and rice wrapped in a sausage casing, or link. Each 10-ounce package sold in grocery stores contains two links and is shipped 12 per carton. Ten-pound bulk packages sold to restaurants and delicatessens contain approximately 30 links. Lester M. Crawford, head of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service, said consumers ``should not unwrap or taste the product'' and should return it to where it was purchased. Crawford said the Centers for Disease Control confirmed the presence of Listeria monocytogenes while investigating a case of listeriosis, the disease caused by the organism. Listeriosis was described as ``a rare but potentially serious'' disease. Most vulnerable are those with weakened immune systems, including infants, the elderly and the chronically ill. Symptoms in adults include the sudden onset of flu-like symptoms such as fever, chills, headache, backache, and sometimes abdominal pain and diarrhea. In newborns, symptoms include respiratory distress, refusal to drink and vomiting. Consumers with question about the recall may phone the toll-free USDA meat and poultry hotline at 1-800-535-4555 between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m. EST, Monday through Friday. Callers in the Washington, D.C., metropolitan area may call 447-3333.
